title: Ithamar
text:
In the <a href="Torah">Torah</a>, Ithamar () was the fourth (and the youngest) son of <a href="Aaron">Aaron</a> the High Priest. Following the construction of the <a href="Tabernacle">Tabernacle</a>, he was responsible for recording an <a href="inventory">inventory</a> to ensure that the constructed Tabernacle and its contents conformed to the vision given by God to <a href="Moses">Moses</a> on <a href="Mount%20Sinai">Mount Sinai</a>.
Kohen.
After the death of his two eldest brothers, <a href="Nadab%20and%20Abihu">Nadab and Abihu</a>, when they had been punished by the Lord for performing an unauthorized incense offering, Ithamar served as a <a href="Kohanim">priest</a> along with his elder brother, <a href="Eleazar">Eleazar</a>, and Ithamar and Eleazar are regarded as the direct male ancestors of all <a href="Kohen">Kohanim</a>.
 records an incident when <a href="Moses">Moses</a> was angry with Eleazar and Ithamar, for failing to eat a sin offering inside the Tabernacle in accordance with the regulations set out in the preceding chapters of Leviticus regarding the entitlement of the priests to a share of the offerings they made on behalf of the Israelite people.
During the travels of the <a href="Israelites">Israelites</a> in the <a href="Wilderness%20of%20Sin">wilderness</a>, Ithamar was responsible for the work of the sons of <a href="Gershon">Gershon</a> and <a href="Merari">Merari</a>, the carriers of the Tabernacle fittings and structures, whilst Eleazar was responsible for the work of the sons of <a href="Kohath">Kohath</a>, who carried the cult objects (the <a href="Ark%20of%20the%20Covenant">ark</a>, the <a href="Altar%20%28Bible%29">altar</a> and the <a href="Menorah%20%28Temple%29">lampstand</a>).
He was also in charge of the work of the <a href="Levites">Levites</a> in general.
Descendants.
According to <a href="Samaritan">Samaritan</a> sources a civil war broke out between the sons of Ithamar (<a href="Eli%20%28Bible%29">Eli</a>) and the sons of <a href="Phinehas">Phinehas</a> {a son of <a href="Eleazar">Eleazar</a> son of Aaron the High Priest} which resulted in the division of those who followed Eli and those who followed High Priest <a href="Uzzi">Uzzi ben Bukki</a> at Mount Gerizim Bethel (a third group followed neither). Likewise according to <a href="Samaritan">Samaritan</a> sources the high priests line of the sons of Phineas died out in 1624 with the death of the 112th High Priest Shlomyah ben Pinhas when the priesthood was transferred to the sons of Ithamar; see article <a href="Samaritan">Samaritan</a> for list of high priests from 1613 to 2013-the 131st high priest of the Samaritans was <a href="Elazar%20ben%20Tsedaka%20ben%20Yitzhaq">Elazar ben Tsedaka ben Yitzhaq</a>; the 132nd high priest was <a href="Aharon%20ben%20Ab-Chisda%20ben%20Yaacob">Aharon ben Ab-Chisda ben Yaacob</a>; the 133rd high priest is <a href="Aabed-El%20ben%20Asher%20ben%20Matzliach">Aabed-El ben Asher ben Matzliach</a>.
Burial site.
The burial site of Ithamar is associated with the "<a href="Hill%20of%20Phinehas">Hill of Phinehas</a>" as related in the Bible and is attributed with the location of the village of <a href="Awarta">Awarta</a> in the <a href="Samaria">Samaria</a>n section of the current day <a href="West%20Bank">West Bank</a>. Due to the uncertain security situation, the <a href="Israel%20Defense%20Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> limits visits by <a href="Jew">Jew</a>s to one annual night close to 5 <a href="Shevat">Shevat</a> on the <a href="Hebrew%20calendar">Hebrew calendar</a> (around January or February).
